title: 111_hr3737
content: The "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009" may be cited as the Act. It includes a Microloan Credit Building Initiative. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to require intermediaries to provide credit reporting information to major credit agencies for borrowers receiving loans under this subsection. The Small Business Act now requires intermediaries to report credit information to major credit agencies for borrowers receiving loans. This process includes providing payment activity details to the agencies through the Administration or independently. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS. Amends Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act by removing "short-term" in various paragraphs. SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require experience in making microloans to startup, newly established, or growing small business concerns. The amended Small Business Act now requires experience in making microloans to startup, newly established, or growing small business concerns, with at least 1 full-time employee having 3 years of experience in this area. The amended Small Business Act now requires experience in making microloans to small business concerns, with at least 1 full-time employee having 1 year of experience providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing to $1,000,000 and $7,000,000, with the possibility of treating it as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate by the Administrator. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance by increasing the percentage from 25% to 35% in the Small Business Act. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program for providing technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing or operating small businesses. The Young Entrepreneurs Program offers technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing or operating small businesses and acquiring financing. A young entrepreneur is defined as an individual who meets certain criteria. The Young Entrepreneurs Program provides technical assistance to individuals aged 25 or younger who have resided in the area served by the intermediary for at least 2 years. The Young Entrepreneurs Program requires young entrepreneurs who receive technical assistance to make a good faith effort to establish or operate their small business in the geographic area served by the intermediary. Deferred repayment may be an option for small business owners. The Young Entrepreneurs Program requires young entrepreneurs to establish or operate their small business in the geographic area served by the intermediary. Small business owners may defer loan repayment for up to 6 months. SEC. 8. INTEREST RATES AND LOAN SIZE amended to increase loan size from $7,500 to $10,000. SEC. 9. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the Administrator to submit a report to the Committees on Small Business of the House of Representatives and the Senate within 90 days after each fiscal year, detailing information on the microloan program. The Senate requires a report on the microloan program, detailing intermediary names, loan amounts, non-Federal contributions, and the number of microloans made. The report on the microloan program includes intermediary names, loan amounts, non-Federal contributions, and the number and amounts of microloans made to specific groups like women, low-income, veteran, and disabled entrepreneurs. The microloan program report includes details on intermediary assistance provided to various groups such as low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs, including marketing, management, and technical support. Women entrepreneurs are also highlighted in the report. The microloan program report details intermediary assistance to women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs, including job creation and retention. The microloan program report includes details on intermediary assistance to women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs, focusing on job creation, repayment history, and business success after receiving microloans. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can provide grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers under the Small Business Act. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. Section 20 of the Small Business Act is amended to authorize $80 million in technical assistance grants, $110 million in direct loans, and $10 million in interest assistance grants for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Section 20 of the Small Business Act authorizes $80 million in technical assistance grants, $110 million in direct loans, and $10 million in interest assistance grants for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Authorization of appropriations is provided for these sums as necessary. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS. The Administrator shall issue regulations to carry out this Act and its amendments within 180 days of enactment. Passed the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009.
